ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I wouldn't recommend taking it if you are pressed for time or plan on doing a lot of extra-curriculars.

French 110 is pretty much what is to be expected of a beginning language class. There are both oral and grammar lessons. It is quite a bit of work each week, but if you stay on top of your lessons it is too difficult. The instructors are very easy to work with and I would definitely recommend taking it if you have any interest in this language.

FREN 110 was a very great class. Professor Vysosias is a really great instructor. You finish the course with a good range of vocab and the ability to use different tenses. There is a big workload: a weekly test, weekly composition, daily homework, and a final - but if you're interested in learning the language take the course! It is a very fun class.

French 110 is a fantastic course! The Yale French department is really one of the best in the world. The professors are all amazing (Vanessa Vysosias is particularly wonderful! Very sweet and kind!). I had heard rumors that L1 French was insanely work-intensive and was hesitant to take it, but in reality, the workload is not that bad. If you manage your time well, it's completely do-able. That being said, I wouldn't recommend taking this as a fifth class. You'll learn a huge amount in just one semester and it's a great experience!

I would absolutely recommend this course if you're truly interested in learning the language. You need to have a real desire to put in the time and effort to learn French. So long as that's true for you, it is a great course. You'll quickly learn and become comfortable and confident speaking French.
Yes, I would recommend it to another student. It requires a lot of careful listening and reading to get the vocabulary, but it was an enjoyable course.
